0.text:
VICKI: Ladies and gentlemen, good evening
and welcome to the Royal Society, the UK's

7.text:
national academy for science. My name is Vicki
Bruce, I am one of the vice-presidents of

12.text:
the British Academy and this is a joint event
between the British Academy and the Royal

17.text:
Society, and I am vice president for public
engagement and tonight's event is exactly

24.text:
the kind of event that we are trying to do
more of, as part of our public outreach. Before

32.text:
I introduce tonight's speakers, I just have
to run through some housekeeping announcements,

38.text:
so I get the housekeeping job. Firstly, can
I ask people to ensure not that your mobile

45.text:
phones are switched off, but they are switched
to silent, because we do encourage those that

51.text:
wish to tweet, to tweet during the event.
But please make sure they are on silent. Secondly,

58.text:
there are no planned fire evacuations this
evening so in the event of an alarm going

62.text:
off it probably means something serious and
we will have to leave the building, so you

67.text:
would need to evacuate through fire exits
which are at the front, middle and rear of

71.text:
the room, I am not going to do the airline
demonstrations of where those are. And I am

77.text:
not sure we have got lights guiding you to
them, but anyway. There are live subtitles

83.text:
provided throughout the event; these are provided
for the benefit of people who might find it

87.text:
difficult to hear what's said, I believe that
the people who are going to be using those

94.text:
subtitles know to sit on this side of the
room and will be able to see the subtitles,

99.text:
I hope so anyway, and I should also tell you
that this evening's event is being webcast

104.text:
live and recorded for the Society's archives.
Now, on to the event proper. I am really delighted

112.text:
to be introducing this event, it has been,
as I said, organised jointly by the Royal

118.text:
Society and the British Academy, as part of
their respective public programmes. Now if

122.text:
you want to find out more about those programmes
please do pick up some of the material and

127.text:
leaflets from outside. The Royal Society,
as we saw on the slides shown earlier, was

134.text:
founded in 1660, the oldest scientific academy
in continuous existence and aims to recognise,

141.text:
promote and support excellence in science.
The British Academy is the UK's national body

147.text:
for the humanities and social sciences, the
academy aims to inspire, recognise and support

153.text:
high achievement in the humanities and social
sciences throughout the UK and internationally.

158.text:
Now, turning to tonight's speakers. The host
for tonight's event is Zeinab Badawi. Zeinab

168.text:
has the very distinguished record as a journalist
and television presenter, formerly for the

175.text:
ITV and now for the BBC, and is currently
Chair of the Council of the Royal African

181.text:
Society. Talking with Zeinab tonight is Professor
Richard Leakey, Richard Leakey is a Kenyan

189.text:
paleoanthropologist, conservationist and public
figure. In the 1960s, Richard led multiple

195.text:
successful expeditions to the shores of Lake
Turkana in Kenya, finding stone age tools,

201.text:
skulls and the remains of early humans. Among
the discoveries was Turkana Boy, a near complete

206.text:
skeleton of a 1.5 million-year old Homo erectus,
the most complete early human skeleton ever

212.text:
found. Beyond anthropology and as well as
leading the National Museum of Kenya, Richard

217.text:
has been politically influential for many
years, his tough anti-corruption and conservation

222.text:
stance as head of the Kenya Wildlife Service
took a hard line against poaching doing much

227.text:
to save elephant and rhino populations. Tonight
I am sure we will be hearing much more about

233.text:
this remarkable career. Ladies and gentlemen,
please join me in welcoming Zeinab Badawi

240.text:
and Professor Richard Leakey. (Applause).
ZEINAB: Thank you very much indeed, Vicki.

253.text:
Good evening, any Excellencies who may be
in the audience, ladies and gentlemen, it's

258.text:
my great pleasure and privilege and honour
to be amongst you all today and to be hosting

264.text:
this event, we will be having a conversation
and then there will also be an opportunity

269.text:
for you to ask some questions. You know we
talk so much about globalisation these days,

274.text:
don't we, but in fact the greatest global
superpower of all time is Africa because it

279.text:
gave rise to the greatest global product,
us, human beings, the greatest global species,

285.text:
you're all African exports, some of us more
recent than others, such as myself, I was

291.text:
born under the African sun, in the Sudan,
but I moved here to the UK when I was two.

297.text:
But our guest of honour today is somebody
who has stayed in his home continent, I am

303.text:
very glad to hear that, but his reputation,
of course, spreads far and wide, far beyond

310.text:
Africa, and we have all benefitted tremendously
from his life's work and, of course, that

315.text:
is Dr Richard Leakey, a man I have admired
for so many years from afar but this week

321.text:
I had the wonderful opportunity to meet him
up and get close, and Richard, you told me,

327.text:
when we had lunch earlier this week, that
you have a very low boredom threshold and

331.text:
that explains why he has had more careers
in his seven decades than most people would

340.text:
in however many lives they may have. So that
explains it. As Vicki said, you have been

347.text:
a paleoanthropologist, in conservation, and
also as a politician, and still going strong

354.text:
and despite all the trials and tribulations
that you have gone through sometimes, he is

358.text:
always smiling, a truly wonderful person.
So Richard, you, the Leakey family rather,

365.text:
also, are best known for your work in fossils,
discovery of fossils, which throw light on

371.text:
the origins of humankind which, of course,
is a subject that fascinates everybody and

377.text:
children and adults alike. So let's start
off by talking a little bit about your work

382.text:
in that field. It is now accepted that human
beings originated from Africa but that wasn't

388.text:
always the case, was it? It was a long journey,
and in fact your father and mother, Mary Leakey,

395.text:
an archaeologist, and Louis Leakey, a palaeontologist,
started work when the theory was beginning

401.text:
to gain a bit of credence but there was still
a bit of resistance for various reasons.

407.text:
RICHARD: I think the resistance was very strong
in fact, in the early part of my father's

413.text:
career, the idea was that if indeed we had
evolved, which was the first question, the

421.text:
second question was surely not from Africa.
And there was a greater preference given to

429.text:
China, or Indonesia, this would be - it would
be better if it was Britain, but Piltdown

435.text:
showed that hadn't been the case so shifting
gear, Asia was a possibility, but Africa,

444.text:
please no. And it's taken a long time, I was
just last week in a part of the United States

451.text:
who shall be nameless where absolutely no
still persists, but I think it's a vociferous

460.text:
minority we are now dealing with and I think
the vast majority of people in the - what's

466.text:
the word I would like to use?
ZEINAB: A polite one?

469.text:
RICHARD: In the world that I am familiar with,
accept African origin. Whether the African

475.text:
origin is fully accepted in China or Pakistan
remains to be seen, I have a feeling the message

481.text:
hasn't really been promoted there, and my
contacts with Chinese still would prefer a

486.text:
Chinese ancestor, if not for us, for them.
ZEINAB: That is because, I suppose - most

492.text:
of you will know but it was Charles Darwin
who particularly in his Ascent of Man in 1871

499.text:
started looking at the fact that the African
gorilla and African chimpanzee, most like

505.text:
us, the chimpanzee in particular, the two
not related to us, but since they were both

511.text:
common only to Africa, he thought that therefore
human beings originated in Africa but it wasn't

517.text:
until 1924 that Raymond Dart, in the Kalahari
desert, discovered some fossil bones known

526.text:
as Taung child and that was part of the genre,
the Australopithecus africanus, but that was

539.text:
the key discovery that made people think - actually,
it said, look, human origins could have been

547.text:
in Africa because up until then hominid fossils
had only been found in Asia or Europe.

552.text:
RICHARD: The Taung baby or child was seminal
in that it did for the first time draw public

560.text:
attention to an alternative to China or Indonesia,
or Java as it was then thought of, but the

567.text:
Taung baby was a baby, it wasn't us, and it
quickly developed a reputation of simply being

575.text:
an ape man and it was still considered even
in later years - it didn't in any way deny

584.text:
that the pithecanthropus of Asia were better
candidates.

589.text:
ZEINAB: But it's fair enough to start saying
that that's when the focus started shifting

597.text:
and then again in 1936 with Robert Broom again
in southern Africa when he discovered fossil

602.text:
bones which gave rise to a group known as
Paranthropus, am I getting these right? And

613.text:
again, that was a kind of hominid fossil but
it was your parents who in 1959 discovered

620.text:
bones in East Africa, in the Olduvai, a part
of Tanzania, and that was the first time that

626.text:
the story started shifting east, and those
bones were known as Zinj, part of the Australopithecus

633.text:
group. Do I pass all these tests?
RICHARD: You are doing well so far, but it

641.text:
is still early. I think the australopithecines,
Broom's work, later on Raymond Dart's work,

650.text:
were well established in South Africa, there
was no precise knowledge of how long ago they

656.text:
had lived, I think the common sense, up until
the late 50s, was that maximum half a million

665.text:
years and the discovery that my mother made
in 1959 of a skull of something called Zinjanthropus

672.text:
was important not only because it was the
first East African find but it was extremely

678.text:
important because it could be dated, the first
time we had a real date for a human ancestor

686.text:
and it was dated 1.75 million, dated not of
the bone but the sediments it was in, and

692.text:
that was a shock to the system to realise
that there was at least three times more amount

697.text:
of years between us and our fossil ancestors
than we had thought and that started a whole

703.text:
era of research in eastern Africa where there
were many sites, as we now know, that yielded

709.text:
remains of hominoids and hominids in contexts
where dating was possible.

715.text:
ZEINAB: And then again another big Leakey
family discovery in 1961, and that was essentially

725.text:
by your brother, Jonathan, who discovered
fossils which we think probably are the earliest

735.text:
precursor to us, human beings, Homo habilis,
handyman, in other words, for those of you

745.text:
who don't speak Latin, so tell us about the
significance of that because that really - Homo

750.text:
habilis is right up there.
RICHARD: I think what was important was at

754.text:
the same time that Zinj had lived and at the
same time as some of the australopithecines

759.text:
had lived in South Africa, there was evidence
that somebody or something was making stone

765.text:
implements, and my father was determined to
find the author of the stone industries, the

772.text:
archaeology, and when he had only got Zinj,
paranthropus, as generally known, it was thought

779.text:
he was the tool maker so when my older brother
Jonathan found a totally different type of

786.text:
early hominid with a much bigger brain case,
much smaller teeth and other features that

793.text:
made it clearly not a typical australopithecine,
they decided that this was evidence of two

800.text:
lines, and my father then decided that the
best candidate for the tool maker was the

806.text:
specimen that Jonathan had found and he called
it Homo habilis, the handyman, they had bones

811.text:
of the hand, and bones of the foot, and certainly
the hand was capable of the sort of flexible

819.text:
thumb that gave it a precision grip and that
then started this whole discussion about the

823.text:
complexity of lineages at that period in time
and the question then was easier settled,

829.text:
that maybe the Zinj group became extinct and
Homo habilis went on to become other things

834.text:
and ultimately us. Were it so simple.
ZEINAB: We are trying to keep it simple because

838.text:
I am sure our audience are aware that there
are lots and lots of discoveries but I will

843.text:
come to the complex lineages in the other
branches in a moment, but just to finish what

847.text:
leads to us, Homo sapiens, then in 1964, your
father, Louis Leakey, found a skull which

855.text:
he thought belonged to a new group called
Homo erectus and then, of course, your team's

861.text:
major find in, well, Homo erectus was also
in Olduvai - but then in 1984, in Turkana

871.text:
in northern Kenya, not Tanzania any more,
your team discovered what became known as

876.text:
Turkana Boy and he was part of the Homo erectus
group and we think that that again is definitely

884.text:
one of our precursors.
RICHARD: Reflecting on it, I think the way

887.text:
I would see it today and remembering it then
was the discovery of the skull by my father

892.text:
in 1964, firmly placed Homo erectus in Africa.
Now those who wanted an East Asian origin

902.text:
for us and believed Homo erectus led to us
said, well, Homo erectus obviously came into

907.text:
Africa, so that's no problem, by that stage
they could move around and this was just a

914.text:
migrant into Africa. They still didn't want
to see or accept an African origin for large

922.text:
brained tool-making ancestors. So later at
Lake Turkana, when we found a number of fossils,

929.text:
best epitomised by the Turkana Boy, then it
is quite clear that Homo erectus in Africa,

937.text:
in east Africa, predated the Homo erectus
in China and Indonesia, there are more recently

945.text:
discovered Homo erectuses in Northern Europe,
in the state of Georgia, which used to be

950.text:
part of the Soviet Union, and those are dated
at around 1.75 million years. Once again,

959.text:
the issue raised, could Homo erectus have
come from the outside into Africa, and although

965.text:
I think the jury may, by some, be considered
still out, I think the majority of people

972.text:
accept that the European Homo erectus at 1.75
was part of an African group that left Africa

981.text:
at that time, and the reason is because there
seem to be antecedents for Homo erectus in

987.text:
Africa but nowhere else.
ZEINAB: That's clear because Homo erectus

990.text:
we believe also gave rise to Neanderthal man,
as one of the groups possibly that went into

996.text:
Europe?
RICHARD: Now you are lowering your grades.

1000.text:
ZEINAB: I thought they did. Because Neanderthal
- okay, let me put it a different way then.

1007.text:
I was doing ever so well up until then.
RICHARD: Yes, you were.

1011.text:
ZEINAB: I am a historian, not a palaeontologist.
So you say there are these branches and it

1018.text:
may have died out. So when we look at the
origins of humankind, what would be a good

1023.text:
analogy, to see it as a tree with lots of
branches, and all those branches led to a

1031.text:
dead end, they may have developed, and then
there was the one branch that continued and

1035.text:
led to us, or is it more like a river that
kind of branches out into different streams

1042.text:
and then that river, the streams all come
together subsequently and we are made up of

1048.text:
little parts of all those streams?
RICHARD: Probably a bit of both. I think you

1055.text:
are getting into -
ZEINAB: The analogy is more complex than the

1057.text:
answer, isn't it?
RICHARD: We are getting into an area where

1059.text:
we still have a lot to learn, but Neanderthal
doesn't come into it until much later. I think

1065.text:
the Homo erectus material known from 1 million
to maybe half a million different parts of

1073.text:
the world, are beginning to show an increasing
set of traits that remind you of more primitive

1081.text:
Homo sapiens, such as Neanderthal, but not
Neanderthal. You see this predominantly in

1088.text:
South East Asia and in Europe, where Neanderthal
is obviously characteristic. But as work is

1095.text:
now being done in different parts of Africa,
at the same period of time, somewhere between

1099.text:
100 and maybe 300,000 years, there are lots
of things being discovered now that make it

1106.text:
very clear that this move towards us had many
threads in the tape, and which dies out, which

1119.text:
goes on, which comes together, which is reknitted,
much has to be done, but what I think is important

1126.text:
to say is that the early Homo sapiens from
Africa are clearly extremely important in

1133.text:
understanding the story of the origin of modern
humans, there are new techniques, the study

1140.text:
of DNA, mitochondrial and other that are beginning
to unravel some of this, and I think those

1147.text:
of us who work solely with fossils need to
be a little more cautious with our prognostications

1153.text:
on what something is until we get a bit more
information on what the DNA may be telling

1158.text:
us. Unfortunately DNA doesn't fossilise very
well and we have very little that goes back.

1164.text:
ZEINAB: We know that DNA shows our closest
relative is the chimpanzee, which is closer

1170.text:
to us than to the gorilla and we share so
much of our DNA with them. We are essentially

1176.text:
a sub-group of the primates, of which there
are, I don't know, 400 species or whatever,

1182.text:
so is it right to say - there was that find
in Chad in West Africa in 2001 of bones, Sahelanthropus

1190.text:
which was thought perhaps to be a common ancestor
to the apes, chimps or whatever, and us, and

1198.text:
we went our separate ways at about 7 million
years ago, would that be fair?

1203.text:
RICHARD: That is how it has been presented.
Unfortunately when you have so little evidence,

1212.text:
you have only got one specimen to compare
with things that haven't yet been found, conclusions

1218.text:
of that kind are much easier to reach, than
if you have a lot of other specimens, and

1224.text:
I think one of our difficulties is that the
work that has been done in Central Africa

1228.text:
and Chad at around 7 million years is producing
fossils which are certainly reminiscent of

1233.text:
later australopithecines and hominids, but
they are just at the moment a jaw, parts of

1242.text:
a skull - a good skull, it is certainly not
us, it is certainly not an australopithecine,

1246.text:
but until you get more of the specimen, of
the body, the legs and arms, saying it was

1252.text:
upright may be premature; saying it had left
the trees permanently may be very premature.

1258.text:
So I think we have got to be very cautious.
We can't really go back more than 4.5 million

1263.text:
years with any confidence, and now the fossils
from Kenya and slightly younger Ardipithecus

1268.text:
in Ethiopia.
ZEINAB: I was going to ask you about that,

1271.text:
Lucy is someone people have heard about, she
was dated to 2.3 million years, discovered

1277.text:
in the mid-1970s in Ethiopia and she is part
of the Australopithecus afarensis group. There

1286.text:
was a lot of excitement saying she is where
it all started, just put her into context

1293.text:
for us.
RICHARD: It is an interesting and important

1300.text:
find, at that time in the study of human origins
it was one of the more complete specimens

1305.text:
where we had parts of the head and parts of
the body, dated around 3 million give or take,

1313.text:
and at that time nothing else was known to
have existed, because it either hadn't existed

1319.text:
or it hadn't been found. The authors of the
paper putting forward Lucy or afarensis as

1328.text:
this stem of human origins took a very strong
position on that and being a bit awkward,

1335.text:
I and a number of others said: well, maybe
not. Maybe there are already two things going

1344.text:
on and maybe you're just hyping this, and
in paleoanthropology, hype is quite a useful

1350.text:
thing in fundraising.
ZEINAB: Is it a case of "my bones are better

1356.text:
than your bones"?
RICHARD: Very much, and please don't look

1360.text:
at mine at the moment. I'll bring them out
slowly, slowly.

1365.text:
ZEINAB: So that's put Lucy into some context
for us. Then just again to finish on this

1372.text:
issue of recent discoveries, thinking very
much of Homo naledi discovered in this dark

1378.text:
chamber in caves 30 miles from Johannesburg
quite recently by Lee Berger and his team

1384.text:
where they found 1,550 bones which looked
like they had been deliberately placed there,

1390.text:
which has brought up the southern claim. The
undercurrent to all these fossil discoveries

1397.text:
in Africa is your working in the east, did
it all start in East Africa or did it all

1403.text:
start in southern Africa, and Lee Berger's
find, people say that has brought up the southern

1408.text:
claim. Two questions there, what do you think
about the discovery there, too early to tell,

1413.text:
do you think they were deliberately buried?
Is the question too long? Sorry, and then

1418.text:
the other one was -
RICHARD: No, the answer may be!

1420.text:
ZEINAB: And then the other one was, what is
this east versus south?

1427.text:
RICHARD: Chauvinism.
ZEINAB: Are you the east chauvinist?

1430.text:
RICHARD: I was. The point we need to make
is Africa at that time was not riven by boundaries,

1442.text:
we need to look at Africa at that time as
stateless and a mosaic of environments in

1450.text:
which different animals survived, co-existed,
moved into and out of. Some of these creatures,

1457.text:
after they died, their bones were preserved
in caves or sedimentary traps and in some

1463.text:
circumstances, some of these sites can be
dated because whilst they were in the process

1469.text:
of burial, volcanic ash settled on the ground
from a nearby volcano and you can date volcanic

1474.text:
ash fairly precisely and so in some cases
you have a dated sequence of deposits in which

1483.text:
fossils are found superimposed as you go up
the ladder, this is 3 million, this is 4 million,

1489.text:
or 1 million or 2 million. The case isn't
so simple in South Africa because if there

1494.text:
was volcanic ash, it didn't get into the caves,
so the techniques for dating the South African

1500.text:
fossils are very open to discussion still.
And in the case of Naledi, the bones were

1507.text:
lying on the surface of a cave floor so there
is nothing left that was covering them. Now,

1516.text:
if you read the reports, they were beautifully
preserved, complete skeletons. They are not

1525.text:
Homo sapiens and looking at the evidence that
has been presented and looking at the papers

1532.text:
that have been written and published, there
are clearly aspects of those fossils that

1537.text:
are very, very reminiscent of us, Homo sapiens.
But to claim an age for it, when no date has

1544.text:
been found, is stretching the point. One point.
Second point, there is no question that they

1553.text:
are completely new set of fossils representing
a species or a stage, that we have never seen

1561.text:
before, and one that is most similar to is
Floresiensis, the Hobbit man from the Pacific,

1570.text:
which is a tiny little Hobbit, which now people
say is a small remnant population dwarf of

1578.text:
Homo erectus, maybe, maybe not, we don't know.
But there are little people around, but those

1584.text:
were 17,000 years old. Now, if you are going
to take skeletons of articulated individuals

1594.text:
from fetal ages to fully adult grannies and
inter them deep inside a cave, 240m from the

1604.text:
entrance, and the entrance is so narrow that
you have really got to get model-like people

1613.text:
to skinny their way through these holes, with
very small buttocks and very small frontals,

1622.text:
very petite, and you have to have light. And
there are no mammals that see in absolute

1631.text:
dark, as far as we know. Bats got round it
in caves where there is no light by developing

1639.text:
echolocation. Sea mammals have got at it by
the same method, by echolocation. How a primate

1647.text:
is going to burrow down without rope and twine
and flash lights and take in 15 individuals

1654.text:
and leave them lying around on the surface
and bacteria is not going to get at it over

1658.text:
the suggested 3 million years, leaves one
slightly sceptical.

1663.text:
ZEINAB: I think we would agree with that,
the way you have portrayed it.

1668.text:
RICHARD: What has worried me, and let me say
this, and I won't dwell on it any more, what

1672.text:
worries me is so much hoopla has been made
of this in the social media that people now

1678.text:
- when there is backtracking and people go,
maybe it wasn't like that, maybe it was a

1684.text:
more conservative interpretation, maybe there
was another entrance to the cave, then many

1688.text:
of the naysayers about human evolution say,
these paleoanthropologists are just dummies,

1694.text:
they don't know what they're talking about,
they pump it up to the sky and it comes crashing

1699.text:
down, evolution is rubbish; evolution is not
rubbish, we do know that we are a process

1705.text:
of evolution and we have very good evidence
about our own ancestors.

1708.text:
ZEINAB: I also asked you about the fact that
they deliberately buried them, which is something

1714.text:
that humans do, so that really raises the
question of what made up Homo sapiens? Obviously

1723.text:
habitual bipedalism, as you said, with Homo
habilis is critical because it leaves the

1728.text:
hands free, but what else made us human, Homo
sapiens, that differentiated us from everything

1736.text:
else?
RICHARD: I would hesitate - it's a sociological

1739.text:
question.
ZEINAB: You said the large brain and that

1740.text:
kind of thing.
RICHARD: The large brain is important, but

1745.text:
you must know some large brained people who
are pretty dumb. I don't think you can take

1751.text:
one character and say "big heads are human".
ZEINAB: You have got a big head, be careful!

1756.text:
RICHARD: I know, and I am human, but I have
a few who aren't, they are human. I think

1763.text:
we have to be very careful about this, but
clearly cognition, the ability to see things

1768.text:
that aren't yet - to put things in time and
space, to have the ability to talk about things

1773.text:
that were yesterday and as well as tomorrow,
and to have the facility of using our brain

1780.text:
through our hands, to fashion things and to
fix things, and to plan things, and to set

1787.text:
traps, this is a complex set of characteristics
that came through time, as to when they would

1795.text:
have given us the ability to aspire to be
elected a Fellow of the Royal Society, much

1800.text:
later, but are we sure, if they had known
of the Royal Society, they wouldn't have had

1805.text:
that aspiration? Hard to say. But I think
we have got to look at this in the longer

1809.text:
term, and I think what is very important about
this is we are very special in some aspects,

1815.text:
but other aspects, we are not at all special,
and to draw a hard line is very, very difficult

1823.text:
in living creatures, let alone fossil creatures.
ZEINAB: Your mother was an archaeologist and

1826.text:
she spent a great deal of time analysing the
tools that were discovered in Africa, how

1833.text:
they were used and what they were used for
and so on, which throws light on how early

1839.text:
humans or similar hominids or whatever conducted
their affairs, but a lot of that is extrapolation,

1846.text:
isn't it --
RICHARD: I think what she was trying to do

1849.text:
and what archaeologists of that period, looking
at the older than 1 million or older than

1854.text:
half a million were trying to do, is saying,
this is how they could have been used, not

1859.text:
necessarily how they were used. I think we
often miss that. We also see stone and bone,

1864.text:
the only things that are preserved, as the
ABC of human behaviour. Not reflecting on

1870.text:
the fact that skin and twine and traps and
all sorts of other manner of things might

1878.text:
well have been part of the life's material
culture that we don't record. So I think we

1884.text:
have got a very simplistic view of the status
of stone tools. I think what is important

1888.text:
is to realise stone tools gave access to a
meat diet, which is important, because meat

1896.text:
is rich in calories and it comes in reasonably
large packages, even if you don't hunt you

1902.text:
can scavenge and if you can find a dead animal
that somebody else killed and cut some meat

1908.text:
off it, it's a very valuable commodity because
you can take it with you and share it. So

1914.text:
I think meat eating is probably one of the
most important things that come along and

1919.text:
I don't think it means we were man the hunter,
that's not what I'm talking about. I'm talking

1924.text:
about man the scavenger, successful scavenger
and what is interesting is our colleagues

1929.text:
now have got stone implements going back to
3.3 million years, so way back before there

1937.text:
were large brains, way back probably before
a lot of things we assume make us human, there

1945.text:
was an animal or an ape, of course both, taking
big stones and smashing them on other stones,

1955.text:
presumably to smash things like tubers and
gristle, skins, which our human teeth then

1963.text:
couldn't chew, but once you smash it up, you
can put it in your mouth and masticate it

1969.text:
and swallow it, so stone implements were the
beginning, and somebody smashed a rock on

1976.text:
another rock and cut themselves and then thought,
I can use that on something else, and I would

1987.text:
have thought it was a serendipitous beginning
to tool makers.

1993.text:
ZEINAB: Becoming hunters rather than gatherers.
Then the storers, and then the agriculturalists

2001.text:
and so on which leads to us, and we know as
you said that primates, even today, some use

2008.text:
tools in a very primitive way. Just to finish
off on the origins of humankind, really homo

2014.text:
sapiens, we only go back 75,000 years, modern
humans?

2021.text:
RICHARD: No.
ZEINAB: Go on then.

2025.text:
RICHARD: From the studies of mitochondrial
DNA and other DNA work that has been done,

2032.text:
everybody living today seems to have a relationship
to a population that was confined to Africa

2039.text:
some 70-80,000 years before the present, maybe
slightly less.

2045.text:
ZEINAB: Isn't that what I just said, about
75,000 years ago?

2050.text:
RICHARD: No, you said Homo sapiens.
ZEINAB: No, us, people here in this audience,

2058.text:
the Royal Society.
RICHARD: Strangely, 100,000 years ago, in

2059.text:
fact, almost 200,000 years ago, there were
people around in Africa, and probably Ethiopia/Kenya

2066.text:
were the best examples, that anatomically
would have been entirely acceptable in comparison

2073.text:
to anyone in this room and they clearly have
to be anatomically modern humans. But the

2079.text:
DNA doesn't suggest there is anything of them
in us. So what happened more recently for

2086.text:
that emigration to take place? We don't know.
But something happened. And there was clearly

2091.text:
massive climate change at the time, the connection
between Lake Turkana and the Nile re-established

2099.text:
itself, people seem to have got out, not only
out but south and west. Was it language? Or

2106.text:
is it something we still don't understand?
ZEINAB: Up until about, what would it be,

2111.text:
20,000 or 15,000 years ago, we were all black?
RICHARD: Well, all the suggestions that I

2119.text:
hear geneticists talking about is that the
colour switch was very recently put on, 12,000

2125.text:
years probably, and blue eyes probably even
more recently, and when you hear of people

2131.text:
coming back into Africa, they probably were
dark people.

2134.text:
ZEINAB: It does put racism in a certain light.
RICHARD: Skin deep.

2138.text:
ZEINAB: You said at the beginning how there
is no question that evolution is the thing

2143.text:
but just briefly on the fact that there is
resistance, not only in America as you talked

2147.text:
about, where the creationists are strong as
a force, but even in Africa itself, the irony

2153.text:
of this continent being the cradle of humankind,
there are people who again subscribe to the

2161.text:
creationist concept.
RICHARD: I think what happened, Zeinab, is

2166.text:
there was always - well not always, there
was traditional religion, which involved origins

2172.text:
and involved Gods and destiny, how long it
goes back I don't know but when the slave

2178.text:
trade and contact with the northern hemisphere,
the Arabs and the Europeans came in, introduced

2186.text:
the two major religions that affect Africa
today, that was Islam and Christianity and

2192.text:
although we in Africa, sub-Saharan Africa
particularly, have fought against colonialism

2196.text:
and suggested it was an evil thing the whites
did to Africa, to a large extent they did

2202.text:
it because they wanted to save African souls,
why I don't know, but that was the idea behind

2208.text:
it. And in the post colonial, freedom fighting
nationalist era, we tried to get rid of everything

2217.text:
colonial but the thing we swallowed without
trace was Christian belief in Genesis and

2225.text:
it seems to me that the very thing they want
to get rid of has taken root deeply, so there

2230.text:
is opposition but it's opposition coming from
missionary education, about the bible. In

2237.text:
Islam, you would know from your part of the
world there are also stories that allow evolution

2243.text:
but not of us. And this, I think, is a reflection
perhaps, let me stick to the Christian thing,

2251.text:
is that subconsciously, if you allow a thought
for a minute on the idea that God made us

2261.text:
in his image, and then the scientists come
along and change the image of us, at what

2269.text:
point do you say: wait a minute, we're getting
too far from what God should look like, when

2274.text:
you produce Lucy, or an Australopithecus.
I think that's part of the problem. How do

2282.text:
you draw the line? What did God create? Obviously
the solution, without wishing to offend anybody,

2288.text:
is he didn't create anything, we created it,
God, much easier to understand, and we need

2294.text:
to, because God can solve everything and when
we didn't have our own science or explanations,

2300.text:
you can't live with doubt, so you give an
Almighty the power to explain what's going

2305.text:
on, most times it's wrong, but we haven't
completed the circle yet, we will.

2312.text:
ZEINAB: In about five minutes - because obviously
you are eminent in this field of paleontology,

2318.text:
you are a paleoanthropologist, but in 1968
you became director of Kenya's national museums

2327.text:
and then in 1989 you were invited to head
the Kenya Wildlife Service so you moved away

2333.text:
from the fieldwork for a while then, but you
showed your typical courage, determination

2340.text:
and vision and not fearing, swimming against
the tide, in terms of conservation, you were

2346.text:
very concerned about elephant and rhino poaching
and so on, and, of course, we see that today,

2351.text:
with Prince William, for instance, just this
week, talking about the fact that when his

2355.text:
daughter reaches 25, people are going to say,
"Well, once upon a time there were elephants

2360.text:
that were roaming this earth", and then all
the recent cases we have had, Cecil the lion

2366.text:
being killed in Zimbabwe and the elephant
more recently there. Looking at conservation,

2372.text:
how worried are you about that scenario of
no elephants or rhinos in 25 years' time could

2379.text:
come to pass in Africa?
RICHARD: I think it assumes and presumes that

2385.text:
the status of wildlife is set on a trajectory
that will always fail. I don't accept that.

2393.text:
I think we can understand why there is poaching,
which is access through the commodity, which

2400.text:
is fortunes, bad pay for the rangers, poor
sentencing of offenders, lack of professionalism

2407.text:
in the service, but change those, poaching
will stop. Change the attitudes to ivory and

2416.text:
rhino horn by looking at the market and changing
its views, there will be no need for poaching.

2422.text:
Poaching is only done because you can make
money out of it and if a ranger can make more

2426.text:
money selling one elephant tusk than a year's
salary, hell, I would poach. So we have to

2433.text:
be realistic. I don't think the elephants
have gone, the elephants have taken a beating,

2437.text:
they are taking a beating at the moment. The
rhino has almost gone in most countries, but

2442.text:
all these species, if we can keep enough genetic
diversity going and we can educate people

2446.text:
and give people a better sense of worth, they
will come back and we don't want to bring

2454.text:
our wildlife back so tourists can enjoy it,
of course they should enjoy it, but we want

2459.text:
to bring wildlife back so our people can enjoy
it, so middle income people can take their

2464.text:
vehicle, with their seven kids and mother-in-law,
and spend a weekend in the park, marvelling

2471.text:
at these animals. That's why we'll keep it.
Not because, with the greatest respect, Prince

2479.text:
William thinks we should.
ZEINAB: No, I was just saying that he's the

2484.text:
latest person to have talked about this.
RICHARD: And he is a good guy, don't get me

2489.text:
wrong.
ZEINAB: He loves the elephants.

2491.text:
RICHARD: That's true.
ZEINAB: But you made a lot of enemies when

2495.text:
you were in this field of trying to stop the
poaching and so on.

2497.text:
RICHARD: That's what they say.
ZEINAB: You had a lot of criticisms and so

2501.text:
on and I know you won't mind my saying this,
but in 1993 you had a plane crash, because

2505.text:
you can fly, and sadly that led to the amputation
of your legs from the knee down in 1993 and

2511.text:
sabotage was suspected but never proved and
I know you feel we will never know who may

2518.text:
have been responsible for that, but that led
to you in 1994 going into politics, you became

2524.text:
the leader of the Safina opposition party.
Safina in Swahili means a boat, a bit like

2529.text:
Noah's Ark. And in 1997 you got a seat in
opposition in parliament, so that really from

2536.text:
the mid 1990s was your political career and
then the president at the time, Daniel arap

2542.text:
Moi invited you to head this commission whereby
you would spearhead the reforms to improve

2550.text:
the way the Civil Service worked in Kenya
and also to improve the governance structures

2556.text:
and the institutions and so on, so just really
touching on your political career, because

2563.text:
you stepped down in 2001, and you said that
was the end of my political career, did you

2567.text:
enjoy being a politician, do you feel you
achieved anything in terms of trying to get

2572.text:
the right governance structures in place?
RICHARD: I think we need to put one or two

2577.text:
corrections to what you said, very general.
I did become head of the public service and

2584.text:
in charge of the government and I did get
the authority to appoint a special team of

2590.text:
permanent secretaries to reform the government,
and during the process of the reform, the

2596.text:
one objective was to turn the economy round,
and to get the IMF, the World Bank and other

2600.text:
donors back in place. Once we did it, we were
less important and within two years, we were

2607.text:
gone. Did I enjoy it? I have enjoyed everything
I have done. It was tremendous fun. Imagine

2613.text:
a whole country, 550,000 people, obliged to
say "yes, sir"! Even if you're completely

2623.text:
wrong. What a power! I enjoyed it thoroughly
and we did make a difference, but I got bored

2629.text:
again, I told you.
ZEINAB: You told me you got bored again, in

2633.text:
2000, and then you went back to your first
love, the fossils and so on and you are now

2638.text:
part of this wonderful initiative, the Turkana
Basin Institute, you are working alongside

2645.text:
mostly Stony Brook University in Long Island
in the United States along with other educational

2650.text:
institutions, Helsinki University and UCL
here in London and you really are - you are

2657.text:
a magnet for people wanting to work in this
field, studying various aspects of palaeontology

2664.text:
because the Turkana Basin, Lake Turkana on
both sides of its shores, Somalia, Kenya and

2671.text:
Ethiopia, you feel is the area which really
holds the clues for the origins of humankind

2678.text:
and you really want to get this TBI, Turkana
Basin Institute, to develop it even more,

2684.text:
attract more funding.
RICHARD: The Turkana Basin Institute is an

2687.text:
attempt to get researchers to do research
where the fossils are being found, to give

2692.text:
the local people a stakeholding in it, to
give the local people a sense of participation

2696.text:
and pride and to create a First World standard
facility in our country that will attract

2704.text:
scholars from everywhere and who will come
and leave, if not with praise, at least satisfaction.

2713.text:
Unfortunately, in our country at the moment,
and this is true in many developing countries,

2716.text:
governments have many priorities, and putting
money into research on human origins and the

2722.text:
sciences that aren't developmentally oriented
isn't very likely, and so the national museum

2731.text:
basically hasn't got the funds to do what
needs to be done so I thought, we will put

2734.text:
in a private sector facility, very ambitious,
but it's working, we have raised -

2740.text:
ZEINAB: Not for profit.
RICHARD: We have raised a lot of money, we

2742.text:
are getting very good support from many parts
of the world.

2745.text:
ZEINAB: You should say, we haven't got enough
funding, so people here can bring more in.

2749.text:
RICHARD: Look at them, they are not going
to give me money tonight. You can read your

2756.text:
audience! [laughs] Let's not hide that. But
it's worked. It's now become a point of pride

2766.text:
in Kenya, particularly amongst the Turkana
people, that this is a success story, they

2770.text:
own it, they like it, they want it.
ZEINAB: It's very good and we do hope that

2775.text:
people in their own ways will be able to support
it. So we have about 20 minutes or so for

2780.text:
you to ask some questions to Dr Leakey, there
are a couple of microphones here, ushers,

2786.text:
just hand the microphones. Do you mind if
we go there, because the microphone is close?

2792.text:
Keep your questions very short, name an organisation
if relevant. Gentleman in the beard. Stand,

2802.text:
please, and project.
FLOOR: Thank you. You talked a little bit

2808.text:
on this mystery of what happened between 200,000
years ago and 80,000 years ago, when we have

2815.text:
anatomically modern humans but we don't have
the big exodus or complicated culture. Steven

2823.text:
Mithen has this idea that people got this
cognitive fluidity in their minds where people

2831.text:
could mix different ideas from different domains
and then suddenly you have religion, that

2836.text:
sort of thing. What is your best guess about
what happened to cause the explosion of culture

2842.text:
and this new kind of humans from 80,000 years
ago?

2847.text:
RICHARD: The quickest way to answer that is
the fossils that we have thus far from Africa

2855.text:
and outside of Africa don't really help understand
that question that you put. The archaeology,

2863.text:
or the lithics as they like to be referred
to, may, but there is as yet not enough lithic

2871.text:
material in situ that can be directly attributed
to morphology of the hominids that they were

2881.text:
being made by or used by. I think much of
sub-Saharan Africa has been completely ignored

2889.text:
for the last 100 years, in terms of the last
2-300,000 years and we now have the opportunity

2895.text:
to really start collecting data in a way that
was never thought possible. I think we must

2902.text:
answer the question that you pose, but I would
be loath to attempt it tonight because we

2908.text:
have certain facts. There were anatomically
modern people and there are genetic lines

2916.text:
to believe that we are all closely related
to the much more recent population. What happened

2921.text:
and why, next chapter.
ZEINAB: One palaeontologist says when you

2928.text:
look at us and how we got there, it's like
a massive jigsaw puzzle with 500 pieces, we

2933.text:
have got eight from East Africa and four from
southern Africa, that's about it. Don't quibble

2940.text:
with that, it's okay, I am just telling you
what she said. Patricia Kramer said that.

2945.text:
RICHARD: Well, she is wrong.
ZEINAB: I hope Patricia Kramer is not here

2951.text:
with us.
RICHARD: It doesn't matter.

2953.text:
ZEINAB: Yes, debate is good.
FLOOR: Would you offer a view as to -

2957.text:
ZEINAB: Could you stand, it's easier?
FLOOR: I would rather not. Could you offer

2961.text:
a view as to what the lady actually is? Was
it an ancestor, can we say it is an example

2970.text:
of symbolic thought and do you think that
Homo habilis was an ancestor?

2976.text:
RICHARD: I think Homo naledi has aspects that
certainly would incline me to believe it belongs

2986.text:
within the brought concept of that genus homo.
Is everything within the genus ancestral to

2993.text:
us? Almost certainly not. Much depends on
where you place it in time and how it integrates

3002.text:
with other fossils. My impression is with
the exception of Floresiensis nothing else

3011.text:
has been found to make a fair comparison.
If you want to call it a descendant, it doesn't

3023.text:
really matter. What I would like to say is
if it is two or three or even one million

3030.text:
years ago, it has a role in the ancestry of
Homo sapiens, but if it turns out to be only

3038.text:
50,000 years old, can it be an ancestor? The
answer is, well, it's not 50,000 years. I

3046.text:
say maybe it's not but what is its age? And
at the moment we don't know. The interesting

3053.text:
thing is that the majority of the fossils
have been demineralised, and they are not

3059.text:
well fossilised. Now is this because of processes
after fossilisation, where they have been

3065.text:
decalcified or is it because they are fairly
recent and survived 50-60,000 years in a sealed

3072.text:
cave? These are questions that need answering
before I can actually take it any further,

3078.text:
for me.
ZEINAB: Thank you. Gentleman here. Can I see

3080.text:
other hands, that side or this side? Two brief
questions, please.

3087.text:
FLOOR: Did australopithecine give an adaptive
response to vertical body or bipedal walking?

3098.text:
And if we implant a chimpanzee in a human
uterus and if we get a baby from there, can

3109.text:
we have an Australopithecus baby or infant?
RICHARD: I didn't follow the entire question

3119.text:
but the part I did get, which I think is relevant,
is if a chimpanzee and a human, which are

3127.text:
genetically close, had a relationship, could
we produce an Australopithecus? Is that the

3134.text:
thrust of your question?
FLOOR: [off microphone] vertical body and

3143.text:
this structure, this posture, maybe affect
the inside, in Australopithecus times, for

3155.text:
example, body gets more and more vertical.
RICHARD: Upright.

3161.text:
FLOOR: What happened in embryo at that time?
RICHARD: I think the very quick answer is

3170.text:
we did become upright probably over the last
4 million years, not 2 million years. There

3175.text:
are consequences to being upright and walking
on two legs. But I don't think it has a particular

3183.text:
relevance to the arrival of genus Homo or
Homo sapiens, it is one of those incidental

3190.text:
events probably related to adaptation for
different sources of food. We were large bodied

3196.text:
apes and I should think the feeding strategy
was benefitted by being upright, where you

3201.text:
could reach up to things in a more open habitat,
if you were a large bodied ape trying to climb

3206.text:
around small trees, gravity then was probably
like today, the trees break and down you come,

3213.text:
so I think it was probably more to do with
feeding than anything else.

3217.text:
ZEINAB: Thank you. The lady there, we will
have a female.

3219.text:
RICHARD: Then we should look on this side.
ZEINAB: Yes, but this is the only lady I see.

3224.text:
FLOOR: Thank you. I am not a palaeontologist
so excuse my naivete on this question. Can

3232.text:
you use the past to project the future? Can
you in palaeontology perhaps identify which

3238.text:
direction human form is going in? I am not
sure. I am sorry, I had just two very other

3245.text:
simple questions. Do you have a view on the
discoveries of oil in Turkana and what it

3254.text:
means for your institution there? And finally
-

3256.text:
ZEINAB: Oh three? Please. Let's stick with
those two.

3260.text:
RICHARD: I think the discovery of oil in Kenya
is fortuitous, I think the people who have

3266.text:
discovered it and are working on it are very
responsible as an oil company so far, they

3271.text:
have worked extremely closely within the parameters
that the government have set and the people

3276.text:
believe is important. Tullow Oil, who are
the company, I think have set the bar very

3282.text:
high for oil exploration. Oil very seldom
brings nothing but pleasure but I think overall

3289.text:
the country needs oil, if we are going to
deal with our development needs, and our debt

3295.text:
needs, and I think we should try not to be
Nigeria but Denmark, and it's the distance

3302.text:
between the two, but we have the advantage
of being able to look at history and make

3307.text:
choices based on that.
In terms of where we are going as a species,

3311.text:
I haven't the slightest notion, but we are
not evolving in the way these early hominids

3316.text:
did. We are subjecting ourselves to change,
more in our behaviour and our culture, and

3322.text:
that sort of adaptation, there may be minor
changes in specific corners of the world,

3328.text:
but I don't think we are going to evolve any
further, in the sense that we have been talking

3332.text:
about.
ZEINAB: And the primates, a chimp couldn't

3334.text:
evolve any more, very quickly, for instance?
RICHARD: I am absolutely certain they couldn't

3339.text:
and knowing what they probably now know, they
wouldn't.

3342.text:
ZEINAB: We are not going to get a Planet of
the Apes scenario, thank you. Can I just see

3349.text:
the hands very quickly? If you are very quick,
I will take all three and then that's it.

3355.text:
It does help if you stand, if you don't mind.
Thank you.

3359.text:
FLOOR: Hi there. I know Louis favoured a bushy
lineage and advocated hybridisation. With

3367.text:
all the revolution of DNA testing upon palaeoanthropology,
I was wondering what has been your greatest

3374.text:
shock or surprise, and why.
ZEINAB: Okay, thank you. I will take two or

3378.text:
three in one. Your greatest shock and surprise,
and then we'll finish. Yes, the microphone,

3383.text:
who has got it? Ushers, give it to the people
unless you wish to ask a question yourself.

3389.text:
Yes, briefly. If you have got the mic, just
